case_vignette:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of increasing weakness and numbness of the upper extremities for 5 days. During the past 2 days, she has had urinary incontinence not related to sneezing or laughing. Last summer, she had weakness and numbness of her right lower extremity that was worse when she was outside; she regained her strength 3 weeks later. She has no history of serious illness. She has had 10 male sexual partners in her lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an impaired tandem gait. There is mild spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in both upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. The abdominal reflex is absent. Muscle strength in the right lower extremity is mildly decreased. Sensation to vibration and fine touch is decreased over the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? A) MRI of the spine B) EMG C) D) E) Lumbar puncture
Answer: A) MRI of the spine
Explanation: The patient's symptoms of increasing weakness and numbness of the upper extremities, urinary incontinence, and a history of similar episodes suggest a possible diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system (CNS) that can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms. The impaired tandem gait, spasticity, decreased muscle strength, and decreased sensation to vibration and fine touch in the upper extremities are all consistent with MS. The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be to perform an MRI of the spine to look for evidence of demyelinating lesions in the CNS. EMG (electromyography) is a test that measures the electrical activity of muscles and is not typically used to diagnose MS. Lumbar puncture (LP) is a procedure in which a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is removed from the spinal canal and is used to diagnose MS, but it is not the most appropriate next step in diagnosis in this case. LP is typically used to diagnose MS when MRI is inconclusive or when the patient has a high risk of MS. The patient's history of 10 male sexual partners and inconsistent condom use increases her risk of MS, but an MRI of the spine is still the most appropriate next step in diagnosis.
